ThingDef.label: M27 IAR
ThingDef.description: The M27 Infantry Automatic Rifle (IAR) features a heavier, longer barrel and an extended magazine to enable greater amounts of suppressive fire while retaining some of the mobility of a standard M416.

ThingDef.label: M16A1
ThingDef.description: In 1964, the M16 entered American military service and the following year was deployed for jungle warfare operations during the Vietnam War. In 1969, the M16A1 replaced the M14 rifle to become the U.S. military's standard service rifle.

ThingDef.label: C7A1
ThingDef.description: The Colt Canada C7 rifle is a Canadian assault rifle, manufactured by Colt Canada, a variant of the Armalite AR-15, and having similar design and function to the Colt M16A3.

ThingDef.label: SG 550
ThingDef.description: The SG 550 is an assault rifle manufactured by Swiss Arms AG of Neuhausen, Switzerland.

ThingDef.label: L85A2
ThingDef.description: Part of the SA80 family, the L85 is the standard assault rifle of the British armed forces.

ThingDef.label: Steyr AUG
ThingDef.description: Since its adoption as the standard rifle of the Austrian army in 1977, it has seen great success as an export, with a high number of global users praising its ruggedness and excellent handling.

ThingDef.label: Mk.16 SCAR-L
ThingDef.description: Compared to its 20 round carbine counterpart, the heavier Mk. 17, the SCAR-L provides greater target acquisition at longer ranges due to the extended barrel length as well as more controlled fire due to manageable recoil.

ThingDef.label: M416
ThingDef.description: The M416 was developed by a famous German weapons manufacturer as a more reliable version of the classic M16.

ThingDef.label: G36A1
ThingDef.description: The G36 is a 5.56×45mm assault rifle, designed in the early 1990s by Heckler and Koch in Germany as a replacement for the heavier 7.62mm G3 battle rifle.

ThingDef.label: M4A2
ThingDef.description: Visually and mechanically similar to the M16, the M4 Carbine was developed to replace pistols and sub-machine guns at the front lines.

ThingDef.label: FN F2000
ThingDef.description: A Belgian manufactured bullpup Assault Rifle configured in the Tactical setup with top and forward rails for mounting a variety of accessories. The rifle is in use with a variety of Special Forces units.

ThingDef.label: FAMAS G2
ThingDef.description: Standard service rifle of the French military.

ThingDef.label: TAR-21
ThingDef.description: The Tavor is an Israeli bullpup assault rifle chambered for 5.56×45mm NATO ammunition with a selective fire system, selecting between semi-automatic mode and full automatic fire mode.

ThingDef.label: XM8
ThingDef.description: The rifle was designed by German small arms manufacturer Heckler and Koch , and shares design and engineering with their G36 rifle.

ThingDef.label: QBZ-95B
ThingDef.description: Standard service rifle of the Chinese armed forces.

ThingDef.label: M249
ThingDef.description: The M249 has seen action in every major conflict since the 1989 invasion of Panama and has earned a reputation as a reliable weapon. A single M249 can supply suppressive fire equivalent to 15 riflemen.

ThingDef.label: FN Minimi
ThingDef.description: The Minimi(short for French: Mini Mitrailleuse; "mini machine gun") is a Belgian 5.56mm light machine gun developed by Fabrique Nationale (FN) in Herstal by Ernest Vervier. First introduced in 1974, it is now in service in more than 75 countries.

ThingDef.label: Steyr Scout
ThingDef.description: It is intended to fill the role of a versatile, lightMass all-around rifle as specified in Jeff Cooper's scout rifle concept.

ThingDef.label: AK74
ThingDef.description: Fielded as the standard Assault Rifle by the Russian Army. The AK-74 is a reliable and rugged medium range weapon.

ThingDef.label: RPK74
ThingDef.description: Introduced in 1974 together with the AK-74 assault rifle and chambered for the new 5.45×39mm high-velocity cartridge.

ThingDef.label: AKS74
ThingDef.description: Fielded as the standard Assault Rifle by the Russian Army. The AK-74 is a reliable and rugged medium range weapon.

ThingDef.label: AN-94
ThingDef.description: Compared to the standard AK series, the AN-94 requires a significantly higher degree of training. A skilled shooter can effectively engage targets at a longer range than typical Assault Rifles.

ThingDef.label: AEK-971
ThingDef.description: The AEK-971 was developed as a possible successor to the AK-74 series of Assault Rifles and features a unique recoil reduction system.

ThingDef.label: AKS74u
ThingDef.description: Derived from the AKS-74, the AKS-74u is a shortened Carbine with the power of a rifle cartridge but the size of a submachine gun.

ThingDef.label: AK107
ThingDef.description: The AK-107 is a Russian 5.45×39mm assault rifle developed from the AK-100-series.

ThingDef.label: AKM
ThingDef.description: The AKM is a 7.62mm assault rifle designed by Mikhail Kalashnikov. It is a common modernized variant of the AK-47 rifle developed in the 1940s.

ThingDef.label: AKMS
ThingDef.description: The main variant of the AKM is the AKMS (S – Skladnoy – Folding), which was equipped with an under-folding metal shoulder stock in place of the fixed wooden stock.

ThingDef.label: AK104
ThingDef.description: The AK-104 is a shortened carbine version of the AK-103 rifle.

ThingDef.label: SKS
ThingDef.description: Millions of SKS rifles were produced originally for the Soviet Army in 1945 and in China as the Type 56. The SKS is a popular rifle with civilian shooters, and can still be found in a number of arsenals around the world.

ThingDef.label: FN FAL
ThingDef.description: The Fusil Automatique Léger ("Light Automatic Rifle") or FAL is a semi-automatic/selective fire battle rifle produced by the Belgian armaments manufacturer Fabrique Nationale de Herstal (FN).

ThingDef.label: Mk.17 SCAR-H
ThingDef.description: This family of rifles consist of two main types. The SCAR-L, for "light", is chambered in the 5.56×45mm NATO cartridge and the SCAR-H, for "heavy", fires 7.62×51mm NATO.

ThingDef.label: Galil ACE 52
ThingDef.description: The Galil ACE is an Israeli assault rifle.

ThingDef.label: M14
ThingDef.description: M14 rifle, officially the United States Rifle, 7.62 mm, M14, is an American selective fire automatic rifle that fires 7.62×51mm NATO (.308 Winchester) ammunition.

ThingDef.label: SR-25
ThingDef.description: The SR-25 (Stoner Rifle-25) is a designated marksman rifle designed by Eugene Stoner and manufactured by Knight's Armament Company.

ThingDef.label: M39 EMR
ThingDef.description: The M39 Enhanced Marksman Rifle (EMR) is a highly modernized M14 designed to be utilized by USMC designated marksmen.

ThingDef.label: G3A3
ThingDef.description: The G3 is a 7.62×51mm NATO battle rifle developed in the 1950s.

ThingDef.label: M60E3
ThingDef.description: The M60, officially the United States Machine Gun, Caliber 7.62 mm, M60, is a family of American general-purpose machine guns firing 7.62×51mm NATO.

ThingDef.label: M240B
ThingDef.description: The M240 is a General Purpose Machine Gun (GPMG) that was first developed in Belgium and adopted by the USMC in 1991. The M60 was replaced first by the M240G, and subsequently by the M240B which provides commonality between the Marines and the US Army.

ThingDef.label: MG 3
ThingDef.description: The MG 3 is a German general-purpose machine gun chambered for the 7.62×51mm NATO cartridge. The weapon's design is derived from the World War II era MG 42 universal machine gun that fired the 7.92×57mm Mauser round.

ThingDef.label: VSS Vintorez
ThingDef.description: The VSS, also called the Vintorez, is a suppressed sniper rifle that uses a heavy subsonic 9×39mm SP5 cartridge and armor-piercing SP6 cartridge.

ThingDef.label: AS VAL
ThingDef.description: The AS VAL is an integrally suppressed Soviet designed Assault Rifle developed for use in the Spetsnaz.

ThingDef.label: VSK-94
ThingDef.description: The VSK-94 is a 9 mm suppressed sniper rifle developed by the Russia KBP Instrument Design Bureau as a low-cost alternative to the VSS rifle.

ThingDef.label: SVU
ThingDef.description: The OTs-03 SVU is a bullpup configuration of the SVD sniper rifle. The SVU was developed to meet the needs of the security forces of the Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs, such as OMON. The SVU was first seen in use in the First Chechen War.

ThingDef.label: SV98
ThingDef.description: Similar to its Western counter parts, the SV-98 began life as a proven Bolt-Action sporting rifle.

ThingDef.label: SVD
ThingDef.description: Designed as a squad support weapon, the SVD Dragunov enhances a squad's ability by providing long range, rapid, accurate Semi-Automatic fire.

ThingDef.label: Mosin–Nagant
ThingDef.description: The Mosin–Nagant is a five-shot, bolt-action, internal magazine-fed, military rifle, developed by the Imperial Russian Army in 1882–91, and used by the armed forces of the Russian Empire, the Soviet Union and various other nations.

ThingDef.label: Winchester Model 70
ThingDef.description: The Winchester Model 70 is a bolt-action sporting rifle. It has an iconic place in American sporting culture and has been held in high regard by shooters since it was introduced in 1936, earning the moniker "The Rifleman's Rifle".

ThingDef.label: Remington 700
ThingDef.description: The Remington Model 700 is a series of bolt-action rifles manufactured by Remington Arms since 1962.

ThingDef.label: M40A3
ThingDef.description: The M40 rifle is a bolt-action sniper rifle used by the United States Marine Corps.

ThingDef.label: L96A1
ThingDef.description: British made, high performance sniper rifle. Widely used across Europe.

ThingDef.label: FR F2
ThingDef.description: The FR F2 is the standard sniper rifle of the French military. It is designed for shooting at point targets at distances up to 800 meters.

ThingDef.label: HK PSG1
ThingDef.description: The PSG1 is a semi-automatic sniper rifle designed by the German company Heckler and Koch of Oberndorf am Neckar.

ThingDef.label: PKP PECHENEG
ThingDef.description: Another Modernization of a traditional Russian weapon, the PKP Pecheneg replaces the PKM machine gun in service with Spetsnaz units.

ThingDef.label: PKM
ThingDef.description: The PK, is a 7.62 mm general-purpose machine gun designed in the Soviet Union and currently in production in Russia.

ThingDef.label: MP5А2
ThingDef.description: Is a 9mm submachine gun of German design, developed in the 1960s.

ThingDef.label: MP5SD
ThingDef.description: A special version of the famous SMG for quiet operations with redesigned balanced mechanics and muffler. Exclusive intermediate weapon for scouts.

ThingDef.label: UZI Carbine
ThingDef.description: The Uzi has found use as a personal defense weapon by rear-echelon troops, officers, artillery troops and tankers, as well as a frontline weapon by elite light infantry assault forces.

ThingDef.label: PP-19
ThingDef.description: Submachine gun developed in Russia, featuring a helical high capacity magazine.

ThingDef.label: Beretta 93R
ThingDef.description: A modified version of the M9 pistol, the 93R is able to fire in 3 Round Bursts.

ThingDef.label: Scorpion Vz.68
ThingDef.description: Although it was developed for use with security forces and special forces, the weapon was also accepted into service with the Czechoslovak Army, as a personal sidearm for lower-ranking army staff, vehicle drivers, armoured vehicle personnel and special forces.

ThingDef.label: HK UMP
ThingDef.description: The UMP is a submachine gun developed and manufactured by Heckler and Koch.

ThingDef.label: M1911
ThingDef.description: The M1911 is one of the most popular pistols in the world. Adopted in 1911 for the US armed forces, the M1911 served as the primary side arm through to 1985.

ThingDef.label: FN P90
ThingDef.description: Developed in Belgium as a Personal Defense Weapon for vehicle crews, Special Forces and Counter-Terrorist groups the P90 is a compact and capable weapon system.

ThingDef.label: Beretta 92
ThingDef.description: Formally known as Pistol, Semiautomatic, 9mm, M9, the M9 was selected as the primary sidearm of the entire United States military in 1985.

ThingDef.label: M1014
ThingDef.description: An Italian Semi-Automatic Shotgun, delivered to USMC in 1999, the M1014 fires 12 gauge rounds without the need for the pump action seen on the M870.

ThingDef.label: SAIGA 12K
ThingDef.description: This Russian made magazine fed 12 gauge Shotgun is based on the proven AK-47 action and equipped with a folding stock.

ThingDef.label: DAO-12
ThingDef.description: Оriginally developed in South Africa, the DAO-12 is essentially the combination of a revolver and a Shotgun.

ThingDef.label: MK3A1
ThingDef.description: The MK3A1 (AKA Jackhammer) is a fully automatic Shotgun prototype developed in the US.

ThingDef.label: USAS-12
ThingDef.description: A South Korean produced Automatic Shotgun, the USAS-12 was specifically developed for the combat Shotgun role.

ThingDef.label: AA12
ThingDef.description: The Auto Assault-12 (AA-12), originally designed and known as the Atchisson Assault Shotgun, is a shotgun developed in 1972 by Maxwell Atchisson.

ThingDef.label: Remington 870
ThingDef.description: The M870 is an American made Pump-Action Shotgun that has been used by Special Forces units for decades.

ThingDef.label: SPAS-12
ThingDef.description: This Italian made iconic shotgun has seen great success since its introduction on the market during the 1980s.

ThingDef.label: .44 Magnum
ThingDef.description: A .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world, this particular model features a ported barrel, a compact frame for easy carry, and of course, a round that will blow your head clean off.

ThingDef.label: Desert Eagle
ThingDef.description: The IMI Desert Eagle is a semi-automatic handgun notable for chambering the largest centerfire cartridge of any magazine fed, self-loading pistol. It has a unique design with a triangular barrel and large muzzle.

ThingDef.label: Colt Mustang
ThingDef.description: The Colt Mustang is a line of two lightMass, single-action pocket pistols chambered for the .380 ACP cartridge, produced by Colt's Manufacturing Company.

ThingDef.label: Gewehr 98
ThingDef.description: The Gewehr 98 (abbreviated G98, Gew 98 or M98) is a German bolt-action Mauser rifle firing cartridges from a 5-round internal clip-loaded magazine that was the German service rifle from 1898 to 1945, when it was replaced by the Karabiner 98k.

ThingDef.label: MG 42
ThingDef.description: The MG 42 is a 7.92×57mm Mauser general purpose machine gun designed in Nazi Germany and used extensively by the Wehrmacht and the Waffen-SS during the second half of World War II.

ThingDef.label: RPG-7
ThingDef.description: A widely-produced, anti-tank rocket propelled grenade weapon, the RPG-7 has been used in almost all conflicts across all continents since the mid-1960s.

ThingDef.label: M32 Milkor
ThingDef.description: The Milkor MGL (Multiple Grenade Launcher) is a lightMass 40 mm six-shot revolver-type grenade launcher developed and manufactured in South Africa.

ThingDef.label: M79
ThingDef.description: The M79 grenade launcher is a single-shot, shoulder-fired, break-action grenade launcher that fires a 40×46mm grenade, which uses what the US Army calls the High-Low Propulsion System to keep recoil forces low, and first appeared during the Vietnam War. Because of its distinctive report, it has earned the nicknames of "Thumper", "Thump-Gun", "Bloop Tube", and "Blooper" among American soldiers.

ThingDef.label: Carl Gustaf M2
ThingDef.description: The Carl Gustaf is an 84 mm man-portable reusable anti-tank recoilless rifle produced by Saab Bofors Dynamics (formerly Bofors Anti-Armour AB) in Sweden.

ThingDef.label: RPO-Z Shmel
ThingDef.description: The RPO-Z is the incendiary warhead designed to spread fire and ignite targets.
